originalInput: Monstera deliciosa yellow leaves and brown edges, soil constantly wet

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'yellow', 'brown', 'small leaves' and symptoms: 'yellow', 'brown' suggesting insufficient light & photosynthesis issues.
actions: Move to bright indirect light near east/west window
Avoid direct sun which burns leaves
Rotate plant weekly for even growth
Consider grow lights for dark spaces
Gradually acclimate to new light conditions
Use sheer curtains to filter intense light
Supplement with LED grow lights in winter
Monitor leaf color - dark green indicates too little light
diagnoses.eco_tip: Monstera aerial roots can be trained up moss poles - they'll grow stronger and develop bigger leaves! The splits (fenestrations) help the plant survive in its natural rainforest habitat by allowing wind to pass through.

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'brown tips', 'crispy edges', 'wet air' and symptoms: 'yellow', 'brown' suggesting low humidity & dry air.
actions: Mist leaves daily or use humidifier
Place on pebble tray with water underneath
Group with other tropical plants
Avoid heating/cooling vents
Consider bathroom or kitchen placement
Use humidity dome for severely dry conditions
Monitor humidity levels with hygrometer
Keep away from fireplaces and radiators
diagnoses.eco_tip: Monstera aerial roots can be trained up moss poles - they'll grow stronger and develop bigger leaves! The splits (fenestrations) help the plant survive in its natural rainforest habitat by allowing wind to pass through.

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'yellow', 'dropping leaves', 'wet soil' and symptoms: 'yellow', 'brown' suggesting overwatering & root rot.
actions: Let top 2 inches of soil dry before watering
Use well-draining potting mix with perlite or orchid bark
Ensure pot has adequate drainage holes
Consider terracotta pot for better drainage
Water only when soil feels dry to the touch
Improve air circulation around the plant
Check for root rot and trim damaged roots
Use bottom watering method occasionally
diagnoses.eco_tip: Monstera aerial roots can be trained up moss poles - they'll grow stronger and develop bigger leaves! The splits (fenestrations) help the plant survive in its natural rainforest habitat by allowing wind to pass through.

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'small leaves' and symptoms: 'leaves' suggesting light problems & photosynthesis issues.
actions: Move to bright indirect light for most houseplants
Avoid direct afternoon sun which can burn leaves
Rotate plant weekly for even growth and light distribution
Consider grow lights if natural light is insufficient
Gradually acclimate to new light conditions over 1-2 weeks
Use sheer curtains to filter intense direct sunlight
Supplement with LED grow lights during winter months
Monitor leaf color - dark green indicates too little light
diagnoses.eco_tip: Most plants benefit from rainwater - collect it in buckets during storms for chemical-free watering! Grouping plants together creates a microclimate that benefits all of them.

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'falling over', 'mushy' and symptoms: 'holes', 'leaves' suggesting needs support & structural issues.
actions: Add moss pole or trellis for climbing support
Gently tie stems to support with soft plant ties
Don't bury aerial roots - let them climb naturally
Repot if plant is top-heavy and unstable
Use bamboo stakes for temporary support
Train aerial roots to climb the support structure
Consider wall-mounted planters for space efficiency
Regularly check and adjust ties as plant grows

originalInput: Pothos vines are leggy small leaves, indirect light exposure

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'dropping leaves', 'pot bound', 'small pot' and symptoms: 'leaves', 'pot' suggesting overwatering & root rot.
actions: Let soil dry completely between waterings - check with finger test
Check drainage holes aren't blocked and pot isn't sitting in water
Repot if roots are mushy and black - trim damaged roots
Use well-draining potting mix with perlite or sand
Water only when top inch of soil is dry to the touch
Consider terracotta pot for better moisture regulation
Improve air circulation around the plant
Use bottom watering method to encourage deep root growth
diagnoses.eco_tip: Money plants are excellent air purifiers and can remove formaldehyde, benzene, and other toxins from indoor air. Use banana peels as natural fertilizer - bury small pieces in soil for potassium boost!

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'pot dry', 'bright light', 'direct sun' and symptoms: 'leaves', 'pot' suggesting underwatering & dehydration.
actions: Water thoroughly when top inch of soil is dry
Increase watering frequency in summer and hot weather
Consider bottom watering method for consistent moisture
Check if plant needs larger pot or repotting
Use room temperature water to avoid shocking roots
Water in the morning to allow excess moisture to evaporate
Mist leaves occasionally to increase humidity
Consider self-watering pot for consistent moisture
diagnoses.eco_tip: Money plants are excellent air purifiers and can remove formaldehyde, benzene, and other toxins from indoor air. Use banana peels as natural fertilizer - bury small pieces in soil for potassium boost!

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'small leaves', 'leggy' and symptoms: 'leaves', 'pot' suggesting nutrient deficiency & soil issues.
actions: Feed with balanced liquid fertilizer monthly during growing season
Repot with fresh nutrient-rich soil containing compost
Add slow-release fertilizer pellets to soil surface
Use organic fertilizers like fish emulsion or seaweed extract
Add coffee grounds or banana peels as natural fertilizer
Ensure proper soil pH (6.0-7.0) for optimal nutrient uptake
Consider foliar feeding for quick nutrient absorption
Test soil pH and adjust if necessary with lime or sulfur
diagnoses.eco_tip: Money plants are excellent air purifiers and can remove formaldehyde, benzene, and other toxins from indoor air. Use banana peels as natural fertilizer - bury small pieces in soil for potassium boost!
